channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Reporters on ‘Gutter Oil’ Series Assaulted, People’s Daily Says
item.description: The Communist Party news organization said its reporters were attacked and robbed of their cameras and cellphones while investigating “gutter oil,” waste cooking oil that is illegally reused.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:credit: Sim Chi Yin for The New York Times
item.media:description: One researcher estimated that as many as 10 percent of restaurant meals were cooked with tainted oil.

item.title: India Ink: In Modi’s Twitter Diplomacy, Some Notable Omissions
item.description: Narendra Modi thanks, and ignores, world leaders on Twitter.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: By NIDA NAJAR

item.title: India Ink: Many of Bangalore’s Young Chose Strong Leader Over Professionals
item.description: Young voters said they had supported the Bharatiya Janata Party instead of distinguished professionals like former Infosys executives because they were drawn to Narendra Modi’s promise of a stable government and better governance.
item.dc:creator: By SARITHA RAI

item.title: Kremlin Announces Ukraine Pullback, but NATO Doesn’t See It
item.description: Russia said President Vladimir V. Putin had ordered troops to leave border areas, but NATO’s secretary general said he had seen no sign of movement.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: North Korean Performer, Reported Executed, Appears on Television
item.description: Hyon Song-wol was reported to be a former girlfriend of the country’s leader, Kim Jong-un.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: U.S. Charges Chinese Army Personnel With Cyberspying
item.description: The Department of Justice on Monday announced charges against several alleged hackers in the People’s Liberation Army, accusing them of stealing trade secrets from American companies.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT

item.title: Reported Syria Death Toll Rises 10,000 in Less Than Two Months
item.description: An antigovernment monitoring group that is one of the few organizations still attempting to keep an exact count put the total number of victims at about 162,000.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: A Rare, Partial Victory in Saving Remnants of Old Beijing
item.description: In a first, a Beijing resident has won protected status for what remains of two sites of historical value from the city’s cultural authorities.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:credit: Didi Kirsten Tatlow/The New York Times
item.media:description: Cui Juinze stands below the hanging lotus gate at No. 33 Lingjing Lane. The empty rectangles along the top of the gate show where thieves removed carved panels in January.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Boko Haram Suspected in Attack on Chinese Workers in Cameroon
item.description: The Chinese Embassy said 10 of its nationals had gone missing from a camp near the Nigerian border and the identity of the assailants was unknown, but it noted that the area had seen frequent attacks by Boko Haram.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: India Ink: Among Polling Firms, Only One Got the Indian Elections Right
item.description: Today’s Chanakya was the only one to predict the magnitude of both the B.J.P.’s victory and the governing Indian National Congress party’s loss.
item.dc:creator: By MALAVIKA VYAWAHARE
item.media:description: People watching Indian election results on a screen outside the Bharatiya Janata Party office in Mumbai, Maharashtra, on Friday.

item.title: India Ink: After the Election: Writers Weigh in
item.description: A sampling of some of the opinions and analyses published after the Bharatiya Janata Party swept its way to victory in India’s historic election.
item.dc:creator: By NIDA NAJAR
item.media:description: Narendra Modi, prime minister-designate of India, after performing a religious ritual at the banks of Ganges River in Varanasi, Uttar Pradesh, on Saturday.

item.title: Putin Orders Troops Near Ukraine to Return Home
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia ordered troops deployed near Ukraine to return to their home bases and praised the launch of a dialogue with the Ukrainian government.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: India Ink: Analysts Have High Hopes for Big Economic Changes Under Modi
item.description: What is driving much of the optimism is the Bharatiya Janata Party’s ability to pass legislation without the need for coalition partners, who could have potentially blocked policy changes that conflicted with their own interests.
item.dc:creator: By NEHA THIRANI BAGRI
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Construction on the Gujarat International Finance Tec-City, a global financial and IT services hub.

item.title: South Korea to Disband Coast Guard, Leader Says
item.description: President Park Geun-hye of South Korea vowed to dismantle her country’s coast guard because of its failures in responding to the recent ferry disaster.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: A Restoration Puzzle
item.description: In the Yungang Grottoes of China, Zhang Juncai is battling to restore ancient Buddhist artifacts broken by vandals and ravaged by pollution.
item.dc:creator: By JONAH M. KESSEL

item.title: India Ink: Congress’s Rank and File Lament Demise of Party Once Beloved
item.description: Theories abound for the Indian National Congress’s reversal of fortunes, but workers gathered at the party headquarters during the vote count said the culture of the leadership had changed.
item.dc:creator: By SUHASINI RAJ

item.title: Chief of Syria’s Air Defense Dies in Battle Near Capital
item.description: The impact of the death of Lt. Gen. Hussein Ayoub Ishaq was unclear, an expert said, because successors usually await and rebel forces have no aircraft.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD and BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Catastrophic Floods Hit Balkans, Raising Fears for Land Mines and Power Plants
item.description: Torrential rains have fed flooding that has killed dozens in Serbia and Bosnia, with officials saying the region has not seen damage on the same scale since in the 1992-95 civil war.
item.dc:creator: By RICK LYMAN

item.title: South Korea to Disband Coast Guard, Leader Vows
item.description: President Park Geun-hye of South Korea vowed on Monday to disband her country’s Coast Guard because of its failures in a ferry disaster.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Listening Post: As U.S. Looks to Nuclear Deal, Book Faults Handling of Iranian Defector
item.description: A new book asserts that an Iranian intelligence officer who is living in the United States under C.I.A. protection oversaw the bombing of the American Embassy in 1983.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: The American Embassy in Beirut, Lebanon, after an April 1983 attack, said to be overseen by an Iranian intelligence officer.

item.title: Afghan Lovers’ Plight Shaking Up the Lives of Those Left in Their Wake
item.description: However matters eventually turn out for the Afghan Romeo and Juliet who eloped into hiding, a happily-ever-after ending is eluding many of those whose lives crossed theirs.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Zakia and Mohammad Ali. A happily-ever-after ending is eluding many of those whose lives crossed theirs in Afghanistan.

item.title: Ex-General Claims Responsibility for Libyan Parliament Attack
item.description: Militia members using antiaircraft weapons, rocket-propelled grenades and light arms engaged Sunday in some of the heaviest clashes in months in Tripoli.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By SULIMAN ALI ZWAY and KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: Masinloc Journal: A Leviathan Turns Philippine Fishermen Into Desperate Darters
item.description: In a dispute over Scarborough Shoal, Chinese patrols have been chasing away Filipinos whose hometown, Masinloc, depends on fish from the reef.
item.dc:creator: By FLOYD WHALEY

item.title: Workers at N.Y.U.’s Abu Dhabi Site Faced Harsh Conditions
item.description: Workers who built New York University’s new campus said they faced grim conditions, in stark contrast to the university’s pledges to treat them fairly.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By ARIEL KAMINER and SEAN O’DRISCOLL
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Migrant workers, in their tiny apartment in Abu Dhabi, earn as little as $272 a month while building a campus for New York University.

item.title: Turkey Arrests Several Executives Over Mining Disaster
item.description: The initial report about the possible causes of the accident compiled by investigators said that the fire in the mine was not caused by a transformer explosion as originally suggested but by smoldering coal that ignited.
item.dc:creator: By SEBNEM ARSU
